Language, culture, and spatial agency in online survey instrument design





John D. Martin III
7 June 2017

Directionality

I want to start off by talking about the directionality of language. Then I'll give some visual examples of Spatial Agency Bias (SAB), and situate those in the context of interactive interfaces. I'll then talk about how SAB might affect interactions with those interfaces, and show some more concrete examples of survey scales involving SAB. Finally I will discuss some of the ways that I think I might study SAB in the context of a self-administered survey instrument.

English (Roman) script runs left to right (LTR)

⟶



⟵

(RTL) النص العربي يمتد من اليمين إلى اليسار

The Roman script that we use for English runs left to right. We'll abbreviate this as "LTR." Arabic script runs right-to-left (that is what the Arabic at the bottom of the screen says). We'll abbreviate that as "RTL."

Spatial Agency Bias

Spatial Agency Bias (SAB) is a theoretical model suggesting that human agency and interpretation of visual-spatial cues follows the directional orientation of the script belonging to a person’s native language. In addition to script direction the bias is moderated by habituation (exposure to another opposite-direction language may reduce it) and contextual cues related to movement (implied directionality), as well as other linguistic factors related to syntax order (Suitner & Maass, 2016). In other words, people who read left-to-right (LTR) languages (English and other Roman, Greek, and Cyrillic-scripted languages) are expected to interact with and interpret visual-spatial environments differently than people who read right-to-left (RTL) languages (Arabic, Urdu, Farsi, Hebrew).

Elephant

In visual representations, people tend to draw motion according to their expected spatial agency bias unless otherwise directed (Maass, Suitner, & Nadhmi, 2014; Vaid, Rhodes, Tosun, & Eslami, 2015; Vaid, Schubert, & Maass, 2011).

Elephant

So, if you ask an English speaker to draw an elephant, they will likely draw it facing right with motion going to the right.

الفيل

Similarly, if you ask an Arabic speaker to draw an elephant, they are likely to draw it facing left...

الفيل

...with motion going to the left. This works for all sorts of animate figures and inanimate objects: animals, people, cars, boats, etc.

Relative agency

Additionally, spatial agency bias can have an effect on the interpretation of agency in a depicted image (Maass & Russo, 2003; Maass, Suitner, Favaretto, & Cignacchi, 2009/5; Maass et al., 2014). The SAB for your language will help determine which figure you view as being in an agentic position or having greater agency With LTR spatial agency bias, this image would likely be interpreted as a dragon attacking St. George. The motion flows in the direction of the SAB. .

Relative agency

This would likely hold true as well if the two figures are portrayed in equal stature. It still appears as if the dragon is attacking.

Relative agency

If we reverse the images, however, St. George is now likely to be perceived as being more agentic for people with LTR SAB.

St. George

In a Google Image search, you will find a lot of images like this of St. George on the left fighting a dragon on the right.

مار جرجس

In Arabic, a search for Mar Girgis, will find more results like this with St. George on the right fighting a dragon on the left.

Spatial Agency Bias in information objects and interfaces

In the context of information objects, the expectations associated with spatial agency bias may obscure information, increase confusion, or cause people to become frustrated with interfaces. This is particularly of concern when the purpose of an interface is to elicit information, as it may also reduce trust (Joinson, 2001; Joinson, Paine, Buchanan, & Reips, 2008; Joinson, Reips, Buchanan, & Schofield, 2010).
Crossword puzzles are a familiar, seemingly simple, but reasonably complex information object. This one is from the New York Times. They have an embedded, structural SAB.
The "Across" category expects that the cells will be filled in from left to right. Never the other way.
Here is an Arabic crossword from al-Hayat Newspaper.
This puzzle as a reverse horizontal SAB from the NYT puzzle, but is otherwise the same.
Another familiar and similar puzzle with SAB embedded is the word search. This one is a search about Ramadan.
Here are the answers identified.
We can see that there are three avaiable directional options for finding answers. These roughly conform to expectations based on SAB.
In this English word search, we would expect a similar scheme of directions for finding the answers.
These are the most reasonable expectations based on our LTR SAB.
However, this may not always be the case. Puzzles like this that are rendered more "difficult" have more directions available for finding answers.
In this case there is a reverse vertical possibility for answers. This does not conform fully to expectations
Let's see if there are any other reversals.
There is also one reverse diagonal, but not either of the RTL diagonals.
There is also not a RTL horizontal possibility.
In this case the possibilties for finding words are limited to vertical and LTR horizontal/diagonals only.

Spatial Agency Bias in response scales

Why is this important? Interactive interfaces do not just display information to people. They are also used to elicit information from people, including sensitive or critical information. In the case of pain scales, the information being elicited can make a huge difference in how patients’ pain is dealt with.
In pain scales, which should be familiar to practically anyone in the United States who has been to a doctor about an injury, the faces correspond to relative levels of pain. The Wong-Baker scale uses faces to represent these abstract levels.
In the Arabic version of these scales, all of the text changes direction, but the scale direction remains the same. This may have an effect on the way that an Arabic-speaking patient responds.
Incongruencies related to spatial agency bias may have an effect on response, which means that the information being elicited by this instrument may not be accurate.

Investigating Spatial Agency Bias in survey interfaces

The design of response scales is well-researched, with a variety experimentally verified principles to draw from in constructing new items. The visual spatial aspects of response scales also have be researched experimentally, resulting in sets of heuristics that can aid in their construction:
  1. Middle means typical;
  2. Left and top mean first;
  3. Near means related;
  4. Up means good; and
  5. Like (in appearance) means close (in meaning) (Tourangeau, Couper, & Conrad, 2004, 2007, 2013).
These heuristics do not, however, take spatial agency bias into account, which may have unintended effects when applied in other than English/LTR contexts (Toepoel & Dillman, 2011)
One method for assessing the difference in response is setting up A/B or split-ballot type experiments. These would vary the directional valence of the scale items, for instance.
Here is the same set of items with reversed scales.
This approach combined with questions about respondent native language, time spent in ESL environment, exposure to other languages, etc. will help to test for a spatial agency bias moderated by other factors than simply script direction.

Let the games begin...

And in this depiction of St. George and the dragon, I am putting myself in the agentic position on the left and fighting the dragon.

Thank you.





John D. Martin III
